results.title: Use your head
results.brief_description: In this video, Tony Buzan explains how to acquire skills needed in any successful business - effective learning, creative thinking and problem solving. He introduces the key concept of mind mapping and explains how reading power and memory can be improved.

results.title: Use and care of books
results.brief_description: Uses cartoon animation to introduce students to books of various kinds, including library books and textbooks. Emphasizes correct ways of using, handling and protecting books. No other credits available.

results.title: Urinary incontinence: a personal disaster (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Guy Fergusson and Royal Society of Medicine Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Discusses the causes of incontinence and methods of treatment. Endeavours to isolate specific causes and direct the treatment to that cause.
Suitable for medical students and staff.

results.title: Urbanissimo
results.brief_description: This film is a colourful statement on the destruction of nature, city planning, aimless construction and rebuilding, pollution and the revamping of natural life styles that comes with a mechanised society. Modern jazz music and subtle sound effects are used in this entertaining film. This film was included as the finale in the main pavilion of Expo ‘67 in Canada and later screened at the 43rd San Francisco International Film Festival, April 20-May 4, 2000.

results.title: Urban landscape
results.creator_credit: Peter Riding and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Exploring Photography”.
One of a series aimed to improve the viewers’ understanding of urban landscape photography as a creative medium and to increase their awareness of visual options. Several photographers discuss their aims and show their work. Narrated by Bryn Campbell.

results.title: Urban land use (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: John Radcliffe, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Dr.J.Blunden discusses various attempts to analyse and quantify the spatial structure of urban zones, using Chicago as a primary illustration. In particular he considers E.W. Burgess and his concentric zone theory, and Homer Hoyts sectoral model, and both are integrated into a composite model.

Burgess and his concentric zone theory, and Homer Hoyts sectoral model, and both are integrated into a composite model.

results.title: Urban impact on weather and climate
results.brief_description: As man changes the surface of the earth through ever increasing urbanization there are corresponding changes in the weather and climate he must endure. Uses experimental models to show effects on rainfall, temperature, normal wind circulation and surface temperature, and the effects of pollutants. No other credits available.

results.title: Urban alternatives
results.creator_credit: Hans Halberstadt and Arthur Barr Productions
results.brief_description: In an attempt to counter the argument that the city is dead, this film surveys some of the alternatives, constructed by designers and architects working as urban environmentalists.

results.title: Uranus, Neptune and Pluto
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 24 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
William Herschel dicovered the planet Uranus in the late 1700’s. In 1986, the satellite Voyager flew past and sent back pictures of this ice planet. Neptune and Uranus have similar composition, but Uranus, unlike other planets, has an unusual rotation and large tilt, where it may have been hit by a celestial object. Uranus has rings and around it floats the debris from the formation of the solar system. Neptune, although similar to Uranus, has a different atmosphere and a dark spot, similar to Jupiter, as well as thin ring arcs. Triton, one of Neptune’s moons, is the coldest place in the solar system. Pluto was the last planet to be discovered, and because Voyager did not pass by, scientists have had to use other methods such as spectroscopy to determine its composition. It is the smallest planet in our solar system and may be a remanant of planet formation when the solar system was first formed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges

Neptune, although similar to Uranus, has a different atmosphere and a dark spot, similar to Jupiter, as well as thin ring arcs. Triton, one of Neptune’s moons, is the coldest place in the solar system. Neptune, although similar to Uranus, has a different atmosphere and a dark spot, similar to Jupiter, as well as thin ring arcs. Triton, one of Neptune’s moons, is the coldest place in the solar system.
